ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about Chinese culture (calligraphy, painting, philosophy, music, etc.) and improved my speaking, reading, and writing ability.
grammar structures, new vocabulary, writing skills, speaking
How to speak, read, and understand Chinese fluently
I gained a better understanding of Chinese language and culture.

Learned a lot of Chinese vocabulary and grammar structures. A lot of the content in the course is actually relevant to common situations (in my experience), in both formal and casual settings. Practiced a lot of speaking Chinese, along with writing / listening / reading as well, though mostly it was spoken (a lot of content was typed because of the virtual setting, so we practiced typing Chinese as well). The focus was placed mainly on grammar structures and proper sentence structures / making phrases that make sense, rather than on tones or specifics of speaking/writing, as well as on understanding Chinese culture and common Chinese situations/habits.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: Xu laoshi is wonderful and genuinely cares for and wants to support her students. She makes class engaging and fun, and my only regret is that she doesn't teach any of the courses later in the Chinese sequence.
Professor Xu is the best, she knows how to keep us engaged with the material and make class enjoyable
The class was very well designed with lots of opportunity for learning

I LOVED this class and especially my professor, Peisong Xu. I really enjoyed the content that we learned, and how the class discussions were formatted.

No complaints!
Course is relativey straight forward and easy to succeed in if you put in the work. Could be a bit boring though, especially over zoom.

Strengths: professors are very kind and welcoming, and the course is geared to help students succeed. Homework is not too difficult, but it is easy to make many small mistakes in crafting sentences etc. Content is designed to be relevant and applicable to common situations/life, which is very nice. A weakness might be that the teachers like to ask trick-esque questions on tests, which, while helpful for making sure students are paying attention, sometimes feel cheap/not reflective of class material.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I enjoyed the format of this course, and the small seminar made it really easy to discuss everything that learned in class.

Teachers were very very considerate of the learning environment online and actively incorporated feedback, which was really nice. Also instituted lots of more interactive activities in class to make class more engaging.
Zoom discussions were engaging. Teachers also used breakout rooms and Google Jamboard to good effect - we created Jamboards in class that were useful for reviewing materials for tests etc.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if you want to improve your Chinese
Yes. It is an awesome and fun class
yes!! Xu Lao Shi is amazing, and the class is very fun and she makes it easy to learn the content.

If you are a heritage student, 153 will introduce you to a lot more of the cultural components. In my opinion, 153 content/vocab-wise was easier to master than 152, but some of the unit topics could be a bit more boring depending on what you're interested in. Xu laoshi is super super caring though and very genuinely wants to see her students succeed. Definitely recommend for anyone trying to improve their grasp of the language and culture.

Yes. Overall a solid course, whether for fun / learning more Chinese / language credit (or any of the above). Teachers make this course enjoyable with a variety of activities. Content is very practical and overall handy to know, and has helped me in common situations outside the classroom (which is always nice); additionally you get a lot of opportunities to use Chinese to talk about things that you care about (essays/projects), etc. Nice class.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A
This class was just a virtual seminar/discussion format, nothing else.
